title: Clifden Castle Walk Route

images.title: Dieglop, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Atmospheric shot of the ruins. The Gothic Revival castle was built in 1818 for John D'Arcy, a local landowner.

images.title: Drow69, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Farmhouse ruins. To the west of the castle, a substantial enclosed farmyard was constructed. This comprised a grain store, workers' cottages, stable and coachhouse. Next to it was a walled garden, with a well and pond nearby

images.title: Knocko, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Standing Stone and view to the coast. D'Arcy had several standing stones erected on his property. Four remain along the winding path between the gateway and the house. One of them might be a prehistoric worked stone, originating from elsewhere

images.title: Raúl Corral, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Clifden Castle and boats in the water. There's some splendid architecture with a rounded tower to the southeast, a square tower and an entry tower with two round turrets. The estate also includes a large gateway, built in 1815 in the medieval style.

images.title: Bert K., CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
Drow69, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Clifden Demesne with Clifden Castle. Fabulous view over the countryside to the house. Part of the castle ruins is a cow pen.

description: This circular walk visits Clifden Castle and the scenic Sky Road in the Connemara region of County Galway. There's a small parking area just off the Sky Road, to the north east of the castle. From here you can pick up a narrow lane to take you through the nearby Castle Gate and then onto the castle itself. Here you can enjoy views of the early 19th century ruined manor house, the surrounding farmland and Clifden Bay. The route then loops round to the Sky Road where you can enjoy some more fabulous views over the area from the elevated spot. You can extend the walk by heading west along the Sky Road to the coast at Eyrephort Beach. See the Sky Road Walk page for full details.
